SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Oaktree Capital Management LP has entered the race to buy control of Renova Energia SA (RNEW11.SA) with a proposal that would inject fresh capital and help refinance part of the Brazilian renewable energy firm’s debt maturing this year, two people with direct knowledge of the plan said on Wednesday.

By injecting capital, a new buyer would give Light (LIGT3.SA) the chance to exit Renova and reduce the stakes held by the other two members of Renova’s controlling bloc - CiaEnergética de Minas Gerais SA (CMIG4.SA) and RR Participações SA.

Financing conditions for Renova, which was founded in 2001, worsened significantly when a partnership with SunEdison Inc SUNEQ.PK collapsed weeks before the latter filed for Chapter11 bankruptcy protection in the United States.

A transaction with Oaktree could reduce Renova’s short-term debt by 6 percent while bolstering capital at least 13 percent, depending on the conclusion of the Alto Sertão III windfarm project, the same person said.

Renova and Oaktree, which oversees about $100 billion in assets, did not have an immediate comment.
Newfound interest in Renova underscores a view among foreign investors that Brazil’s renewable power industry remains resilient even as consumption suffers with the country’s worst recession ever.
Units of Renova (RNEW11.SA), a blend of Renova's common and preferred shares, have jumped almost 30 percent since January 2 when Reuters first reported that the company could be taken over.
The so-called tag along will be based on the proportion of common and preferred shares contained in Renova’s units - the company’s most widely traded class of stock, the person said.
According to one of the people, who requested anonymity to discuss the matter, both non-binding bids from Brookfield and Oaktree would give equal treatment to minority shareholders.
The people said Oaktree would pay 170 million reais ($51 million) for Light SA’s 16 percent stake in Renova and spend another 1.2 billion reais to dilute Renova’s controlling bloc.
Under the terms of that proposal, Light would get 200 million reais for the stake it has in Renova, which would also get 800 million reais in fresh capital.
Los Angeles-based Oaktree [OAKCP.UL], the world’s biggest distressed debt investor, is competing with Brookfield Asset Management Inc (BAMa.TO) for Renova.
Late on Tuesday, Renova confirmed a July 3 report by Reuters that Brookfield has made a non-binding proposal for control of the company.
Oaktree could opt to refinance Renova’s short-term debt or just a loan with state-controlled Banco do Brasil SA, the person said.
It also involves the refinancing of Renova bank loans maturing this year, freeing up collateral, the people said.
Reuters first reported in April last year that Renova has been looking for a partner and fresh capital.
